title: 105_hr3170
content: Section 1 introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, titled "Gains from Constructive Ownership Transactions" under Part IV of subchapter P of chapter 1. The taxpayer's gain from a constructive ownership transaction with a financial position is treated as short-term capital gain if it exceeds the net underlying long-term capital gain. If it is still treated as long-term capital gain, the capital gain rate is determined based on the applicable rates under section 1(h). The determination of capital gain rates for long-term gains is based on applicable rates under section 1(h) after considering the net underlying long-term capital gain. If gain is treated as short-term capital gain, an interest charge may apply on the deferral of gain recognition. The interest charge on deferral of gain recognition applies if short-term capital gain is treated for a taxable year, increasing the taxpayer's tax by the amount of interest that would have been imposed under section 6601. The taxpayer's tax for a taxable year is increased by interest under section 6601 for periods ending on the due date for the return of tax and on underpayments of tax for prior years related to gain recognition. The taxpayer's tax for a taxable year is increased by interest under section 6601 for periods ending on the due date for the return of tax and on underpayments of tax for prior years related to gain recognition. Any amount payable under this provision affects the taxpayer's deduction for interest paid or accrued during the taxable year. Additionally, any increase in tax due to this provision is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for determining credits. The taxpayer's tax is increased by interest under section 6601 for periods ending on the due date for the return of tax and on underpayments of tax for prior years related to gain recognition. This increase in tax does not count towards determining certain tax credits. The term 'financial position' is defined for this section. The term 'financial position' is defined as any position with respect to stock, debt instrument, partnership interest, or investment trust interest, including futures or forward contracts, short sales, or options. The term 'financial position' encompasses positions related to stock, debt instruments, partnership interests, or investment trust interests, including futures, forward contracts, short sales, and options. Taxpayers are considered to have entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they or a related person hold a long position under a notional principal contract. Taxpayers are treated as having entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract, enter into a forward or futures contract, or are the grantor of a put and holder of a call with respect to the same or substantially identical property. Taxpayers are treated as having entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract, enter into a forward or futures contract, or are the grantor of a put and holder of a call with respect to the same or substantially identical property. This includes transactions with substantially equal strike prices or other transactions that have the same effect. Taxpayers are considered to have engaged in a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract, enter into a forward or futures contract, or are the grantor of a put and holder of a call with respect to the same or substantially identical property with substantially equal strike prices. This section does not apply if all positions in the transaction are marked to market. The section does not apply to constructive ownership transactions if all positions are marked to market. A person is considered to hold a long position under a notional principal contract if they have the right to be paid. A long position under a notional principal contract is defined as having the right to receive investment yield and being obligated to reimburse any decline in value of the property. A forward contract is defined as an agreement where one party receives the investment yield on a property and is obligated to reimburse any decline in its value. The term "related person" refers to individuals as defined by specific sections. The term 'forward contract' and 'related person' are defined in specific sections. 'Net underlying long-term capital gain' refers to the aggregate net capital gain in a constructive ownership transaction. The term 'net underlying long-term capital gain' in a constructive ownership transaction refers to the aggregate net capital gain that would have occurred if the position was acquired and sold on specific dates, with only gains and losses from deemed ownership taken into account. The amount is considered zero unless proven otherwise with clear evidence. The net underlying long-term capital gain in a constructive ownership transaction is determined based on gains and losses from deemed ownership. The amount is assumed to be zero unless proven with clear evidence. If a taxpayer elects the Mark to Market option, subsections (a) and (b) do not apply, and gain or loss is recognized on open constructive ownership transactions. If a taxpayer elects the Mark to Market option, subsections (a) and (b) do not apply, and gain or loss is recognized on open constructive ownership transactions. The Mark to Market option allows recognition of gain or loss on open constructive ownership transactions at the close of a taxable year based on fair market value. Adjustments are made for subsequent realized gains or losses. Proper adjustments are made for any subsequent realized gains or losses from constructive ownership transactions, treating them as ordinary income or loss. The gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction before the close of the taxable year shall be treated as ordinary income or loss if certain conditions are met. An election under this rule may be made. The gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction before the close of the taxable year shall be treated as ordinary income or loss. An election under this rule may be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. An election under this rule can be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. The amendments made by this section apply to gain recognized after the date of the enactment of this Act.
